review.title: Behavior-Based Machine-Learning: A Hybrid Approach for Predicting Human Decision Making
review.abstract: A large body of work in behavioral fields attempts to develop models that describe the way people, as opposed to rational agents, make decisions. A recent Choice Prediction Competition (2015) challenged researchers to suggest a model that captures 14 classic choice biases and can predict human decisions under risk and ambiguity. The competition focused on simple decision problems, in which human subjects were asked to repeatedly choose between two gamble options.

metadata.title: Behavior-Based Machine-Learning: A Hybrid Approach for Predicting Human Decision Making

sections.text: ar Xiv: 161 1.10 228v 1 [cs.L G] 30 NIn this paper, we present our approach to predicting human decision-making behaviour: we propose to use machine learning with traits based on well-established behavioural theories, the basic idea being that these psychological traits are indispensable for the representation of data and important for the success of the learning process. We implement a vanilla model in which we train SVM models based on behavioural traits based on the psychological traits underlying the competitive model. We show that this fundamental model captures the 14 selection distortions and outperforms all other learning-based models in competition. Preliminary results suggest that such hybrid models can significantly improve the prediction of human decision-making and provide a promising direction for future research.

sections.text: Each sample that reflects a problem p is given by 10 parameters: LA, HA, pHA, LB, HB, pHB, LotNum, LotShape, Corr, Amb (the first 10 coordinates of problem space PS). For each block i of consecutive five election attempts, we calculate a property representation f ip consisting of (24 + i-1) characteristics as follows. First, we create a problem beep by converting p's probabilities - pHa and pHb - to their effective form at block i. Specifically, we set pHa = RMS (pHa, i) and pHb = RMS (pHb, i), to: RMS (p, i) if p ≤ 0.02 p + (1 − 1 i) · (1 − p) if p).

sections.heading: 2.2 Learning Algorithm
sections.text: To learn the problem, we chose Support Vector Machines (SVM) [1], a versatile and powerful learning method. We experimented with various kernel selections, and the best results were obtained with a third-degree polynomial nucleus, applying N-fold (for N = 10) cross-validation over the 90 estimation problems. For each block i (1,..., 5), we learned a separate SVM model of attribute representation in block i as described above. 2Experiments 1 and 2, data in tables 2 and 3 in [2].

sections.heading: 2.3 Prediction
sections.text: Faced with a target problem p represented by a feature vector x, the hybrid model predicts the B rates for x sequentially: first B1, the average rates in the first block of "from description" studies, then each subsequent Bi in block i, followed by adjustments based on the problem properties. Specifically, the hybrid model predicts Brates Bi for each block i by performing the following procedure: 1. Set z as the standardized feature representation of the target problem x.2. Specify the SVM model in block i to z to obtain Bi.3. Adjust Bi in the following two cases, taking into account the effective form of the problem Bi, EvA and the features BevB, EvA and SCPT in Block II.

sections.heading: 3 Results and Conclusion
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Results
sections.text: The hybrid model passed the tests provided for by [2], indicating success in capturing all 14 selection anomalies; the MSD value on the estimate (the 90 problems originally supplied to competitors) was 0.74 compared to 0.71 achieved by the base model, with an average of 0.94 and a standard deviation of 0.74 compared to the 25 models submitted to the competition; the MSD value on the test set (60 new problems) was 1.24 compared to 0.98 achieved by the base model, with an average of 1.47 and a standard deviation of 0.89; of the 25 models submitted to the competition, 14 were variants of the base model and the rest were based on statistics, machine learning or other methods. Our model ranked 14th, where ranks 1-13 were all occupied by variants of the base model.

sections.heading: 3.2 Conclusion
sections.text: Our hybrid model outperformed all models that were not variants of the base model, and in particular performed better than all learning-based models that did not use behavioral theories; these results suggest that learning methods alone are not sufficient to predict human decisions, and that the presentation and manipulation of data based on behavioral knowledge is important for the success of these methods, which supports our approach to integrate behavioral traits and adaptations with the powerful machine learning tools to improve their performance; however, the fact that the hybrid model has been rated lower than the base model and its variants suggests that this integration should be further investigated and improved; we believe that a first major improvement in the preliminary results shown in this paper can be achieved by further experimenting with the full range of parameters available for SVM, as well as by trying other machine learning methods; and a second significant improvement can be achieved by learning from a larger training set. Conducting large-scale experiments with online labor markets is becoming increasingly popular with Amazon's growing online workforce.

For instance, in risky choice problems, when the decision is based solely on the description of the problem people tend to overweight rare events [5], while in decisions based on experience they tend to underweight rare events (see review of the experience-description gap in [4]).
Recently, researchers were challenged in the Choice Prediction Competition (CPC) 2015 [2] to propose a model that will be general enough to predict human decisions for a wide space of problems.

The competition focused on 14 well-studied choice anomalies, which included the four biases captured by prospect theory [5] (including overweighting of rare events), and additional 10 biases that were documented in studies of decisions with and without feedback (including underweighting of rare events in repeated settings with feedback).
For the full description of the competition see [2] and the competition website.

Our Approach: The common approach towards solving this problem in behavioral fields is to derive patterns from behavior observed in experiments (in some setting), and then define a model which employs these patterns to make a prediction, all generally based on well-established literature (see, for example, the competition baseline model [2]).
Most of these features are derived from the baseline model provided by [2].

metadata.abstractText: A large body of work in behavioral fields attempts to develop models that describe the way people, as opposed to rational agents, make decisions. A recent Choice Prediction Competition (2015) challenged researchers to suggest a model that captures 14 classic choice biases and can predict human decisions under risk and ambiguity. The competition focused on simple decision problems, in which human subjects were asked to repeatedly choose between two gamble options. In this paper we present our approach for predicting human decision behavior: we suggest to use machine learning algorithms with features that are based on well-established behavioral theories. The basic idea is that these psychological features are essential for the representation of the data and are important for the success of the learning process. We implement a vanilla model in which we train SVM models using behavioral features that rely on the psychological properties underlying the competition baseline model. We show that this basic model captures the 14 choice biases and outperforms all the other learning-based models in the competition. The preliminary results suggest that such hybrid models can significantly improve the prediction of human decision making, and are a promising direction for future research.
